question: On þissum geare ferde seo (micel) #### scipfierd eft on Englalande - In this year the great navy went again to England
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the singular nominative feminine 'scipfierd' so it takes the feminine 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'seo', 'scipfierd' is feminine so 'micel' should take the feminine nominative 'e' ending

question: Se (yfel) #### unrihtwisa cyning spræc mid his yflan tungan - The evil unrighteous king spoke with his evil mouth
explanation: Here 'yfel' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'cyning' so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'se', 'cyning' is masculine so 'yfel' should take the masculine nominative 'a' ending

question: Se (swet) #### mete ðe hie heton monna se him cuom of hefonum - The sweet meats that they call mana which comes from heaven
explanation: Here 'swet' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'mete' so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'se', 'mete' is masculine so 'swet' should take the masculine nominative 'a' ending

question: Dol bið þæt (lytel) #### scip ðe gæð on deop wæter - Foolish is the little ship that goes in deep water
explanation: Here 'lytel' is modifying the singular nominative neuter 'scip' so it takes the neuter 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'lytel' becomes 'lytle' when it gains the singular nominative neuter suffix 'e'

question: On þissum geare sende he þone (eald) #### biscop Wulfstan to þæm stede þe wæs genemned Readingum - In this year he sent the old bishop to the place that was called Reading
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the singular accusative masculine 'biscop' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: He sende þæt (halig) #### lic to þæm mynster - He sent the holy body to the minster
explanation: Here 'halig' is modifying the singular accusative neuter 'lic' so it takes the 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'þæt', 'lic' is neuter so 'halig' should take the neuter accusative 'e' ending

While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'halig' becomes 'halge' when it gains the singular accusative neuter suffix 'e'

question: Se ðe gebigde ðone (heah) #### heofonlican bigels - He who bowed the high vault of heaven
explanation: Here 'heah' is modifying the singular accusative masculine 'bigels' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Words ending in 'h' replace their 'h' with a 'g' before a suffix beginning with a vowel, so 'heah' becomes 'heagan' when it gains the ending 'an'

question: Se deofol gesette hine uppan ðam scylfe ðæs (heah) #### temples - The devil set him upon the summit of the high temple
explanation: Here 'heah' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'temple' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Words ending in 'h' replace their 'h' with a 'g' before a suffix beginning with a vowel, so 'heah' becomes 'heagan' when it gains the ending 'an'

question: He is in ðone deopan grund ðæs hatan leges and ðæs (heard) #### leges - He is in the deep abyss of the hot flame and the hard flame
explanation: Here 'heard' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'leg' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Hwæt synt nu þæs foremeran ond þæs (wis) #### goldsmiðes ban Welondes? - What now are the bones of that renowned and wise goldsmith Weland?
explanation: Here 'wis' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'goldsmiðes' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða wicingas eodon þa to þære (lytel) #### iege þe is genemned Iona - The vikings then went to the little island that is named Iona
explanation: Here 'lytel' is modifying the singular dative feminine 'ieg' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'lytel' becomes 'lytlan' when it gains the singular genitive feminine suffix 'an'

question: Woroldlicra weorca on ðam (halig) #### dæge geswice man georne - On that holy day, let men abstain from worldly works
explanation: Here 'halig' is modifying the singular dative masculine 'dæg' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'halig' becomes 'halgan' when it gains the singular dative masculine suffix 'an'

question: Ic ðe hæbbe aþriet mid ðis (lang) #### spelle - I have bored you with this long speech
explanation: Here 'lang' is modifying the singular dative neuter 'spell' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ac uton don swa swa God tæhte þæt ure (<em>god</em) #### weorc beon on ða wisan mannum cuðe - But let us do as God has taught, that our good works may be so known to men
explanation: Here 'god' is modifying the plural nominative neuter 'weorc' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða (heard) #### þrowunga ðe he adreag - The hard sufferings than he endured
explanation: Here 'heard' is modifying the plural nominative feminine 'þrowunga' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða (eald) #### wunde spræce þa ealdan race - The old wounds speak the old stories
